briefdescription.para: Decide whether a block is non-zero under a simple max-abs rule.

memberdef.argsstring: (const float *W, uint32_t rows, uint32_t cols, uint32_t block_rows, uint32_t block_cols, float threshold, ie_block_sparse_matrix_t *out)
memberdef.name: dense_to_block_sparse

briefdescription.para: Build an ie_block_sparse_matrix_t from a dense matrix in memory.
Microbenchmark comparing dense vs block-sparse GEMV (FP32).

detaileddescription.para:
This benchmark:
Synthesizes a large dense matrix W (rows x cols) and input vector x.
Converts W into a block-sparse representation (BSR) in-memory using the same layout as defined in sparse_format.h.
Runs repeated GEMV operations using: (a) a naive dense row-major GEMV, and (b) ie_gemv_block_sparse_f32 on the block-sparse matrix.
Reports timings, effective density, and a rough memory-traffic estimate.
The goal is to provide a standalone way to measure the potential benefit of block sparsity for large matrices under a simple max-abs block pruning rule.
Defaults: rows = 4096 cols = 4096 iters = 50 block_rows = 16 block_cols = 16 threshold = 1e-3

The pruning rule is:
A block is kept if any element has |w| >= threshold.
Otherwise the block is dropped.

Notes:
This is CPU-only and single-threaded on purpose.
It uses the same BSR format as the engine (see sparse_format.h) and calls ie_gemv_block_sparse_f32 from gemm_block_sparse.c.
